citation.article-title: Geminicoccus roseus gen. nov., sp. nov., an aerobic phototrophic Alphaproteobacterium isolated from a marine aquaculture biofilter.

p.s: Description of Geminicoccus roseus sp. nov.
Geminicoccus roseus (ro.se’us. L. masc. adj. roseus rose colored, pink)
Displays the following characters in addition to those given in the genus description above.
Cells are 1.5–2.1 μm in diameter.
Colonies grown in the light are pink, 1–3 mm in diameter.
Contains carotenoids and bacteriochlorophyll a.
Membranes contain b-type cytochromes; a- and c-type cytochromes may also occur.
Grows from 15 to 45 °C and pH 5.5–11.0, with optimal growth at 30–35 °C and pH 8.0.
Doubling time under optimal conditions is 5 h.
Growth requires sea salt.
Grows on acetate, arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, lactate, maltose, mannose, peptone, propanol, propionate, pyruvate, or tartrate.

Growth not apparent on alanine, amygdaline, asparagine, butanol, butyrate, casamino acids, citrate, fumarate, ethanol, glucose, glutamate, inosite, lactose, malate, mannite, melibiose, methanol, oxalate, rhamnose, saccharose, sorbite, succinate, or xylose.
Gelatin is hydrolyzed.
Acetoin formed but not indole.
Catalase and urease positive.
Cytochrome c-oxidase, beta-galactosidase, arginine dihydrolase, lysine and ornithine decarboxylase, and tryptophan desaminase negative.
Nitrate reduced to nitrite, but not coupled to anaerobic growth.
Nitrite, sulfate, or iron (III) not used as electron acceptors.
Fermentative growth not apparent.
The G+C content of the DNA was 60.3±0.1 mol%.
The type strain (D2-3T=DSM 18922T=ATCC BAA-1445T) was isolated from the biofilter of a recirculating marine aquaculture system in Rehovot, Israel.
